00338  /* Go through the linked list of executable images and verify that they
00339     are correct. At the same time build the executable_table. */
00340  {
00341   const struct executable_image* image;
00342 
00343   for (image=ELF_images_start; 0!=image; image=image->next)
00344   {
00345    unsigned long      image_size;
00346 
00347    /* First calculate the size of the image. */
00348    if (0 != image->next)
00349    {
00350     image_size = ((char *) (image->next)) - ((char *) image) -1;
00351    }
00352    else
00353    {

00355    }

00357    /* Check that the image is an ELF image and that it is of the
00358       right type. */
00359    if (
00360        /* EI_MAG0 - EI_MAG3 have to be 0x7f 'E' 'L' 'F'. */
00361        (image->elf_image.e_ident[EI_MAG0] != 0x7f) ||
00362        (image->elf_image.e_ident[EI_MAG1] != 'E') ||
00363        (image->elf_image.e_ident[EI_MAG2] != 'L') ||
00364        (image->elf_image.e_ident[EI_MAG3] != 'F') ||
00365        /* Check that the image is a 64-bit image. */
00366        (image->elf_image.e_ident[EI_CLASS] != 2) ||
00367        /* Check that the image is a little endian image. */
00368        (image->elf_image.e_ident[EI_DATA] != 1) ||
00369        /* And that the version of the image format is correct. */
00370        (image->elf_image.e_ident[EI_VERSION] != 1) ||
00371        /* NB: We do not check the ABI or ABI version. We really should
00372           but currently those fields are not set properly by the build
00373           tools. They are both set to zero which means: System V ABI,
00374           third edition. However, the ABI used is clearly not System V :-) */
00375 
00376        /* Check that the image is executable. */
00377        (image->elf_image.e_type != 2) ||
00378        /* Check that the image is executable on AMD64. */
00379        (image->elf_image.e_machine != 0x3e) ||
00380        /* Check that the object format is corrent. */
00381        (image->elf_image.e_version != 1) ||
00382        /* Check that the processor dependent flags are all reset. */
00383        (image->elf_image.e_flags != 0) ||
00384        /* Check that the length of t   he header is what we expect. */
00385        (image->elf_image.e_ehsize != sizeof(struct Elf64_Ehdr)) ||
00386        /* Check that the size of the program header table entry is what
00387           we expect. */
00388        (image->elf_image.e_phentsize != sizeof(struct Elf64_Phdr)) ||
00389        /* Check that the number of entries is reasonable. */
00390        (image->elf_image.e_phnum < 0) ||
00391        (image->elf_image.e_phnum > 8) ||
00392        /* Check that the entry point is within the image. */
00393        (image->elf_image.e_entry < 0) ||
00394        (image->elf_image.e_entry >= image_size) ||
00395        /* Finally, check that the program header table is within the image. */
00396        (image->elf_image.e_phoff > image_size) ||
00397        ((image->elf_image.e_phoff +
00398          image->elf_image.e_phnum * sizeof(struct Elf64_Phdr)) > image_size )
00399       )
00400 
00401    {
00402     /* There is something wrong with the image. */
00403     while (1)
00404     {
00405      kprints("Kernel panic! Corrupt executable image.\n");
00406     }
00407     continue;
00408    }
00409 
00410    /* Now check the program header table. */
00411    {
00412     int                program_header_index;
00413     struct Elf64_Phdr* program_header = ((struct Elf64_Phdr*)
00414                                          (((char*) &(image->elf_image)) +
00415                                           image->elf_image.e_phoff));
00416     unsigned long      memory_footprint_size = 0;
00417 
00418     for (program_header_index = 0;
00419          program_header_index < image->elf_image.e_phnum;
00420          program_header_index++)
00421     {
00422      /* First sanity check the entry. */
00423      if (
00424          /* Check that the segment is a type we can handle. */
00425          (program_header[program_header_index].p_type < 0) ||
00426          (!((program_header[program_header_index].p_type == PT_NULL) ||
00427             (program_header[program_header_index].p_type == PT_LOAD) ||
00428             (program_header[program_header_index].p_type == PT_PHDR))) ||
00429          /* Look more carefully into loadable segments. */
00430          ((program_header[program_header_index].p_type == PT_LOAD) &&
00431            /* Check if any flags that we can not handle is set. */
00432           (((program_header[program_header_index].p_flags & ~7) != 0) ||
00433            /* Check if sizes and offsets look sane. */
00434            (program_header[program_header_index].p_offset < 0) ||
00435            (program_header[program_header_index].p_vaddr < 0) ||
00436            (program_header[program_header_index].p_filesz < 0) ||
00437            (program_header[program_header_index].p_memsz < 0) ||
00438           /* Check if the segment has an odd size. We require the
00439              segement size to be an even multiple of 8. */
00440            (0 != (program_header[program_header_index].p_memsz&7)) ||
00441            (0 != (program_header[program_header_index].p_filesz&7)) ||
00442            /* Check if the segment goes beyond the image. */
00443            ((program_header[program_header_index].p_offset +
00444              program_header[program_header_index].p_filesz) > image_size)))
00445         )
00446      {
00447       while (1)
00448       {
00449        kprints("Kernel panic! Corrupt segment.\n");
00450       }
00451      }
00452 
00453      /* Check that all PT_LOAD segments are contigous starting from
00454         address 0. Also, calculate the memory footprint of the image. */
00455      if (program_header[program_header_index].p_type == PT_LOAD)
00456      {
00457       if (program_header[program_header_index].p_vaddr !=
00458           memory_footprint_size)
00459       {
00460        while (1)
00461        {
00462         kprints("Kernel panic! Executable image has illegal memory layout.\n");
00463        }
00464       }
00465 
00466       memory_footprint_size += program_header[program_header_index].p_memsz;
00467      }
00468     }
00469 
00470     executable_table[executable_table_size].memory_footprint_size =
00471      memory_footprint_size;
00472    }
00473 
00474    executable_table[executable_table_size].elf_image = &(image->elf_image);
00475    executable_table_size += 1;
00476 
00477    kprints("Found an executable image.\n");
00478 
00479    if (executable_table_size >= MAX_NUMBER_OF_PROCESSES)
00480    {
00481     while (1)
00482     {
00483      kprints("Kernel panic! Too many executable images found.\n");
00484     }
00485    }
00486   }
00487  }
00488 
00489  /* Check that actually some executable files are found. Also check that the
00490     thread structure is of the right size. The assembly code will break if it
00491     is not. Finally, initialize memory protection. You will implement memory
00492     protection in task A4. */
00493 
00494  if ((0 >= executable_table_size) || 
00495      (1024 != sizeof(union thread)))
00496  {
00497   while (1)
00498   {
00499    kprints("Kernel panic! Can not boot.\n");
00500   }
00501  }
00502 
00503  initialize_memory_protection();
00504 
00505  /* All sub-systems are now initialized. Kernel areas can now get the right
00506     memory protection. */
00507 
00508  {
00509   /* Use the kernel's ELF header. */
00510   struct Elf32_Phdr* program_header = ((struct Elf32_Phdr*)
00511                                        (((char*) (0x00100000)) +
00512                                         ((struct Elf32_Ehdr*)0x00100000)->
00513                                           e_phoff));
00514 
00515   /* Traverse the program header. */
00516   short              number_of_program_header_entries = 
00517                       ((struct Elf32_Ehdr*)0x00100000)->e_phnum;
00518   int                i;
00519   for(i=0; i<number_of_program_header_entries; i++)
00520   {
00521    if (PT_LOAD == program_header[i].p_type)
00522    {
00523     /* Set protection on each segment. */
00524 
00525     update_memory_protection(kernel_page_table_root,
00526                              program_header[i].p_vaddr,
00527                              program_header[i].p_memsz,
00528                              (program_header[i].p_flags&7) | PF_KERNEL);
00529    }
00530   }
00531  }
00532 
00533  /* Start running the first program in the executable table. */
00534 
00535  /* Use the ELF program header table and copy the right portions of the
00536     image to memory. This is done by prepare_process. */
00537 
00538  {
00539   struct prepare_process_return_value prepare_process_ret_val = 
00540    prepare_process(executable_table[0].elf_image,
00541                    0,
00542                    executable_table[0].memory_footprint_size);
00543 
00544   if (0 == prepare_process_ret_val.first_instruction_address)
00545   {
00546    while (1)
00547    {
00548     kprints("Kernel panic! Can not start process 0!\n");
00549    }
00550   }
00551 
00552   /* Start executable program 0 as process 0. At this point, there are no
00553      processes so we can just grab entry 0 and use it. */
00554   process_table[0].parent=-1;    /* We put -1 to indicate that there is no
00555                                     parent process. */
00556   process_table[0].threads=1;
00557 
00558   /* Set the page table address. */
00559   process_table[0].page_table_root =
00560    prepare_process_ret_val.page_table_address;
00561   cpu_private_data.page_table_root =
00562    prepare_process_ret_val.page_table_address;
00563 
00564   /* We need a thread. We just take the first one as no threads are running or
00565      have been allocated at this point. */
00566   thread_table[0].data.owner=0;  /* 0 is the index of the first process. */
00567 
00568   /* We reset all flags and enable interrupts */
00569   thread_table[0].data.registers.integer_registers.rflags=0x200;
00570 
00571   /* And set the start address. */
00572   thread_table[0].data.registers.integer_registers.rip =
00573    prepare_process_ret_val.first_instruction_address;
00574 
00575   /* Finally we set the current thread. */
00576   cpu_private_data.thread_index = 0;
00577  }
00578 
00579  /* Set up the timer hardware to generate interrupts 200 times a second. */
00580  outb(0x43, 0x36);
00581  outb(0x40, 78);
00582  outb(0x40, 23);
00583 
00584  /* Now we set up the interrupt controller to allow timer interrupts. */
00585  outb(0x20, 0x11);
00586  outb(0xA0, 0x11);
00587 
00588  outb(0x21, 0x20);
00589  outb(0xA1, 0x28);
00590 
00591  outb(0x21, 1<<2);
00592  outb(0xA1, 2);
00593 
00594  outb(0x21, 1);
00595  outb(0xA1, 1);
00596 
00597  outb(0x21, 0xfe);
00598  outb(0xA1, 0xff);
00599 
00600  kprints("\n\n\nThe kernel has booted!\n\n\n");
00601  /* Now go back to the assembly language code and let the process run. */
00602 }

void kprinthex ( const register long  value  ) 

Prints a long formatted as a hexadecimal number to the bochs console.

Parameters:
value  the value to be written

Definition at line 84 of file kernel.c.

References outb().

00085 {
00086  const static char hex_helper[16]="0123456789abcdef";
00087  register int      i;
00088 
00089  /* Print each character of the hexadecimal number. This is a very inefficient
00090     way of printing hexadecimal numbers. It is, however, very compact in terms
00091     of the number of source code lines. */
00092  for(i=15; i>=0; i--)
00093  {
00094   outb(0xe9, hex_helper[(value>>(i*4))&15]);
00095  }
00096 }

struct thread_queue ready_queue

The ready queue.

Note:
Linked lists are terminated with a thread with a next index of -1.

Definition at line 22 of file kernel.c.

Referenced by initialize().

long system_time

This variable holds the current system time.

The system time is the number of clock ticks since system start. There are 200 clock ticks per second.

Definition at line 44 of file kernel.c.

union thread thread_table[MAX_NUMBER_OF_THREADS]

Array holding all threads in the systems.

Definition at line 16 of file kernel.c.

Referenced by allocate_thread(), initialize(), thread_queue_dequeue(), and thread_queue_enqueue().

int timer_queue_head

The index, into thread_table, of the head of the timer queue.

The timer queue is a list of threads blocked waiting for the system clock to reach a certain time. This variable is set to -1 if there are no threads in the timer queue.

Definition at line 40 of file kernel.c.
